Award.AwardTitle: Particulate-based Imaging Amperometry for Rapid Measurement of Current Dist ribution

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1133082
PI: Sides

Technical description: The core hypothesis of this project is that colloidal particles can function as probes of local electrochemical current density. The essence of the innovation is using scattered light from colloidal particles during polarization of electrodes. In experiments, colloidal particles will be scattered across test electrodes used in electrochemical cells. Laser radiation introduced at an angle of incidence greater than a critical angle will create evanescent radiation proximate to the electrodes. The particles scatter these evanescent waves as visible light. The particles respond dynamically to local current density, which means that the particles transduce the local current density to light having an intensity that can be measured. Theory will convert the light intensity to a determination of current density. When ensembles of particles are used, the method creates an image of current density on the electrode. Imaging the scattering of a 2D ensemble of particles on a composition spread alloy working electrode during polarization of the film will reveal the regions of high electrochemical activity over the entire sample within minutes, with a resolution of areas as small, or perhaps smaller, than 100 microns on a side. This will mean that a library made from a sample one square centimeter in area will have 104 samples in its collection. The project focuses on oxygen evolution from aqueous solution as the test electrochemical reaction. This reaction is highly irreversible and has been of considerable interest for decades.

Broader significance and importance: There is broad interest in developing high throughput methods for accelerating research. This project focuses on development of a high throughput method for investigation of an electrochemical reaction that is critical to enabling the supply of hydrogen as a fuel. The project will make possible a thousandfold increase in productivity in the search for new electrode materials for carrying out the splitting of water to produce hydrogen and pure oxygen. The concept of imaging amperometry might be the best solution to this problem; if so, the method will be adopted at other laboratories and/or a scientific instrument will be developed by an electrochemical instrument company or a startup. The proposed research has the potential for a large payoff in capability in addition to the richness of its research in education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Problem: Tools for high-throughput research can accelerate the identification of electrocatalyst formulations for water splitting, a topic of much current interest to enable efficient generation of hydrogen for use in fuel cells for vehicle propulsion and remote power generation. Noble metal oxides such as ruthenium and iridium are among the best catalysts for oxygen production, the byproduct of water splitting and the slowest step in the process,  but are expensive. The use of earth-abundant mixed oxides in producing hydrogen would expedite the transition to broader use of fuel cells, but iron oxides  and nickel oxides are not great electrocatalysts by themselves.  The addition of iron to nickel based oxides makes a much better catalyst, synergistically.  The addition of third and fourth components to iron and nickel oxides holds the prospect of even better performance. Unfortunately, traditional search methods would take years to survey the possible combinations.  

Proposed solution: The PI and co-PI of this project invented and investigated a concept called the Imaging Ammeter with the aim of providing a tool for high-throughput research to rapidly develop multi-element catalysts.  Figure 1 is a schematic of the instrument. A power supply energizes a test cell featuring a conductive transparent thin film coating a prism.  Light totally reflects from the electrode/electrolyte interface at angles of incidence above a critical angle.  Evanescent radiation propagates parallel to the electrode. Probe particles are dispersed in the electrolyte above the electrode. Electrostatic repulsive forces levitate the particles and prevent them from sticking.  The particles scatter a fraction of the evanescent radiation as visible light in an amount that depends exponentially on the proximity of the particles to the electrode. When the electrode is polarized and current flows, the electric field in the electrolyte pushes or pulls on the particles, which affects their height above the electrode and hence changes the scattered light intensity. This strong functional relationship between the electric field and the intensity of the scattered light imparts sensitivity to the method. The imaging ammeter allows simultaneous electrochemical characterization of  an area with variations in composition. Myriad colloidal particles added to the electrolyte "report" the local current density via the intensity of the light they scatter when the cell is operating. Imaging of individual particles for this application is impractical at the low magnification level needed to image a macroscopic sample. Thus we  mapped the electrochemical activity by imaging the entire electrode surface.  

Intellectual Merit: We demonstrated the ability of the Imaging Ammeter to image the reactiion rate on mixed oxide nickel/iron electrocatalyst materials. The crucial finding was that nanoparticles of silica enhanced both the robustness of the experiment and resolution of the images.  Figure 2 shows an image of the current density on an electrode where a good catalyst and a poor catalyst were side by side on the electrode.  One could see no difference with the naked eye, but using the apparatus of Figure 1 and the methods developed in the project, one can see the increased activity (brighter parts) relative to the low activity area (dark part).  In Figure 3, we demonstrate the Imaging Ammeter for investigating alloys by putting a small amount of iron at one place on an otherwise uniform film of nickel oxide. The brighter areas of Figure 3 are where the iron oxide synergistically catalyzes the reaction.  Two journal articles have been published and a third manuscript describing the crucial final results is ready for submission.
